en: Interview with Kathy Waltosz, a volunteer with Samaritan's Purse,conducted by Laura Romans. Waltosz provides an overview of Samaritan's Purse and discusses the efforts in helping survivors to sift through ashes of burned homes for valuables. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I've seen a range of heat damage in different fires, and of course when a house burns and it doesn't have any water coming on it, it'll just go up in flames and then it'll get quite hot, to the point where it will consume everything in the house. If there's no water that comes on it when the fire is burned out in a house, you can have a one story house and what's left is about two to three inches of debris."

Can you tell us some about your life, career, and background?
Could you tell us what Samaritan's Purse is, what they do, and how you became involved with them?
Can you tell us some about the other places and disasters that you helped with prior to Gatlinburg?
When did you become aware of the wildfires in Gatlinburg and how did you become involved there?
What was it like when you first got to Gatlinburg?
What was the actual work like? What did a typical day look like when you went out?
On average, how much time do you and your team spend on a property?
How long did you stay and work in Gatlinburg?
Mentioning difference between previous jobs, is there anything else that you've noticed about this wildfire or the community in Gatlinburg?
Is there anything that we haven't talked about related to the fires that you would like to share?

seo.title: Interview with Kathy Waltosz, 2020-06-11 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
